description.narrative: Support to UNESCO's communication and culture sectors with focus on freedom of expression.

United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) är en organisation som bl.a. arbetar med globala frågor inom kommunikation och kultur. UNESCO har skickat en ansökan om stöd till Sida för organisationens arbete med utbildning (ED), kommunikation och information (CI), kultur (CLT) och forskning (SC). Sida DEMO har i bifogad bedömningspromemoria tagit ställning till ansökan om stöd till Cl- och CLT-sektorerna. Det är önskvärt att eventuellt stöd från GLOBPRO, FORSK och DEMO inkluderas inom ett och samma Programme Cooperation Agreement (PCA) med UNESCO i enlighet med bifogat avtalsutkast.
DEMOs förslag till stöd till CI och CLT avser i första hand ett tematiskt stöd till de föreslagna programmen inom CI och CLT, där huvudfokus inom CI-programmet ligger på främjande av yttrandefrihet och medieutveckling och huvudfokus inom CLT-programmet ligger på främjande av yttrandefrihet genom stärkande av policys för främjande av kulturell mångfald.
De föreslagna programmen är väl förankrade i UNESCO Medium-Term Strategy för 2014-2021 (37 C/4) och Programme and Budget för 2014-2017 (37 C/5). Verksamheten är både global och landspecifik, där globala komponenter i huvudsak är normativt orienterade och komponenter på landnivå fokuserar på kapacitetsutveckling, allt emedan det finns ett sampel mellan det globala och landspecifika arbetet. I fokus för verksamhet på landnivå är länder som präglas av ett demokratisk underskott, inklusive inskränkningar inom yttrandefrihet och brist på oberoende media.
Globalt normativt inom yttrandefrihet och medieutveckling bidrar CI-programmet i huvudsak till områdena säkerhet för journalister, yttrandefrihet online och offline, media literacy samt media och jämställdhet. På landnivå bidrar programmet till UNESCOs arbete med lokal radio i Afrika samt andra landspecifika yttrandefrihetsinsatser i Afrika, MENA och Latinamerika inom lagstifnings- och påverkansarbete samt kapacitetsbyggande insatser inom ICT, media och journalistik, vilket är ett viktigt bidrag till att stärka demokratisering och yttrandefrihet i dessa länder. CLT-programmet är starkt förankrat i 2005 års UNESCO konvention för kulturell mångfald som har yttrandefrihet och jämställdhet som grundläggande principer. Kapacitetsutveckling på landnivå fokuserar på förståelse av konventionen och metoder för datainsamlig och uppföljning av konventionen, vilket bl a inkludrerar bevakning av yttrandefrihet/kommunikation. Det globala normativa arbetet fokuserar på att dokumentera och formulera policys, standards och regleringar inom området.
Sverige kommer att stödja UNESCOs arbete för yttrandefrihet under en fyraårsperiod med 80,5 miljoner SEK, med en första utbetalning 2014, som är det första året för UNESCO med dess nya strategiska plan, program och budget. UNESCOs ansökan bygger på en programperiod om fyra år. I och med att programmet start infaller senare än planerat år 2014 så kommer programmets aktivtetsperiod att löpa till och med 30 juni 2018.
Utbetalningsplanen fördelad på delkomponenter i Plus ser ut som följande: Pluskomponent 6107800001 Communication/Empowering Local Radios for ICT: 2014 SEK 735 000; 2015 SEK 10 000 000; 2016 SEK 10 000 000; 2017 SEK 9 000 000 Pluskomponent 6107800002 Communication/Support to Democracy and Freedom of Expression: 2014 6 104 000; 2015 SEK 3 702 000; 2016 SEK 10 396 000; 2017 SEK 11 515 000 Pluskomponent 6107800003 Culture/Enhancing Fundamental Freedoms through the Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions: 2014 SEK 6 661 000; 2015 SEK 6 298 000; 2016 SEK 3 104 000; 2017 SEK 2 985 000.
De komparativa fördelarna med Sidas stöd till UNESCO:s sektorer för kommunikation och kultur är bl.a. att: - UNESCO är det FN-organ med mandat och ansvar för yttrandefrihet och kulturell mångfald - UNESCOs kommunikationssektor är värd för den arbetsgrupp som framställer den normativt viktiga World Trend Report (med tidigare stöd från Sida) samt andra viktiga studier såsom Internet Universiality studien. - Unescos kultursektor ansvarar för 2005 års UNESCO konvention om kulturell mångald som erbjuder ett verktyg för att formulera policys och lagar för god samhällstyrning för skydd och mångfald av kulturella uttryck, baserad på yttrandefrihet - Sidas samberedning samt uppmuntran till samarbete mellan de två sektorerna bedöms kunna bidra till fördjupad förankring av yttrandefrihetsfrågan inom Unesco samt stärka effekter av programmen - Sida, Svenska Unescorådet och Sveriges FN-delegation i Paris betonar samtliga yttrandefrihet samt förbättrad resultatstyrning inom UNESCO vilket stärker Sveriges samlade engagemang och möjlighet att påverka organisationen.
Därför bedömer Sida att organisationen är en viktig global normerande aktör för utveckling av policys, standards, lagstifning och regler för säkerställande av yttrandefrihet och kulturell mångfald.
Bedömning av UNESCOs kapacitet samt system och rutiner för resultstyrning, intern styrning och kontroll har skett i nära samarbete med GLOBPRO och FORSK. Sida har tagit del av olika tillgängliga bedömningar som gjorts av UNESCO: Sveriges organisationsbedömning av UNESCO (2012), UK review Multilateral Aid Review/MAR (2013), Norsk samarbeid med UNESCO (2011), Independent external evaluation of UNESCO (2010), Evaluation of UNESCO/EU Project Expert Facility to Strenthen System of Governance for Culture in Developing Countries (2013), Evaluation of UNESCOs Standard-setting Work of the Culture Sector Part IV (2014), Evaluation of UNESCO's contribution to Strategic Programme Objectives 12 adn 13, Evaluation of Public Service Broadcasting (2014).
Övrigt Svenskt stöd till UNESCO består bla av följande planerade Sida insatser: - För 2014-2017 avser Sida enhet GLOBPRO ge ett stöd till UNESCO Utbildning om 70 miljoner SEK /år - För 2014-2017 avser Sida enhet FORSK avser ge ett stöd till Natural Sciences Sector (SC) med ca 10 miljoner kronor/år.

The intervention supported UNESCO's work and mandate to promote the free flow of ideas by word and image during 2014-2018. In particular it contributed to achieving the strategic objective number 8 and 9 of UNESCO's Medium-term Strategy 2014-2021 (37 C/4): Strategic objective 8: Fostering creativity and the diversity of cultural expressions.Strategic objective 9: Fostering freedom of expression, media development and universal access to information and knowledge. From the outset, in 2014, the intervention consisted of two programmes, referred to as 1 and 2, of which the first consisted of two more or less separate components (1 a) and b)). In 2016 Sida decided on additional support to a project within the framework of the International Programme for the Development of Communications (IPDC), referred to as 3. The first programme 1 a) and b) as well as the additional project support, 3, were implemented by the Communication and Information (CI) Sector. The second programme, 2, was implemented by the Culture (CLT) Sector and was directly linked to the 2005 Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions. The programmes contained both work on standard setting and normative policy development, for example through the production of Global Reports, and capacity building on country level. Gender equality was promoted in the programmes. The title and aims of the programmes/projects were: 1 a) "Promoting democracy and freedom of expression" which aimed to strengthen freedom of expression and democracy through empowering free, pluralistic and independent media at global regional and national levels. Examples of expected results of the programme were: an enabling environment for freedom of expression and information as well as for press freedom and related rights online and offline; a free and safe environment for journalists, media workers and blogers, including the implementation of the UN Plan of Action on the Safety of Journalists and the Issue of Impunity; women and youth are empowered through enhanced capacities in media and information literacy and awareness of freedom of expressions, and through improved representation in media production and content. 1 b) "Empowering local radios with ICT (Information and Communication Technologies)" which aimed to put freedom of expression into practice by exercising accountability in the interest of the public through radio stations' capacities to raise awareness on local issues of concern. 2 "Enhancing fundamental freedoms through the promotion of the diversity of cultural expression" which aimed to enhance the establishment of systems of good governance that are based on fundamental freedoms and that foster the diversity of cultural expressions. Outcome no 1 reads: Governmental and civil society actors participate in transparent and informed policy making processes that promote fundamental principles of freedom of expression as a prerequisite for ensuring the diversity of cultural expressions. Outcome no 2 reads: Countries apply evidence based and informed policy making based on fundamental principles of freedom of expression, gender equality, sustainability, openness and balance. 3 "Defining Internet Universality Indicators" which supported the preparation of a draft framework and a set of "Internet Universality Indicators" as well as a pre-test and pilot of the indicators before final adoption of the framework by the member states of UNESCO. The programmes included objectives on creating synergies within and accross the programmes. An example of one synergy outcome reads "synergies in analysis and advocacy are created in areas of media diversity, freedom of expression and diversity of cultural expressions".

description.narrative: Several interesting and good results have been achieved by the intervention, both expected and unexpected. All programmes except 3 "Defining Internet Universality Indicators" have been evaluated. The summary draws both on results assessed in the final reports and the evaluation reports as well as Sida's assessment. 1 a) "Promoting democracy and freedom of expression" Global scope with a focus on the Arab region, Africa, South East Asia and Latin America. Specific countries targeted are: Ethiopia, Rwanda, Somali, South Sudan, Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Libya, Morocco, Palestine, Syria, Tunisia, Myanmar, Thailand, Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay. UNESCO has through awareness raising and advocacy first and foremost through the World Press Freedom Day celebrations contributed to an enabling environment for freedom of expression, freedom of information, press freedom and related rights, online and offline. The World Trends Report on Freedom of Expression and Media Development (WTR) (exclusively supported by Sweden) has become a reference for Member States, international organizations, civil society organizations and academics. Sida's and Sweden's assessment is that the report could have even greater ambition, spread and impact. UNESCO is still elaborating to find the best format and outreach for the report. UNESCO's global World Press Freedom Days celebrations (WPFD, May 3rd) annually gather more than 900 participants from 90 countries, including key international civil society organisation in the freedom of expression area. WPFD celebrations have contributed to knowledge and awareness raising, coalition building, sensitizing member states, influencing agenda setting through its declarations adopted by the participants. I.e. the global celebration WPFD in Jakarta 2017 adopted a declaration that addressed fake news and Internet issues; the WPFD 2018, the Accra Declaration called on member states to put in place dedicated national mechanisms for the safety of journalists and to respect judicial decisions of regional human rights courts, which fed into resolutions of UNESCO and the Human Rights Council. The WPFD has also become a forum for joint launches of the global flagship reports WTR (CI) and Re:Shaping Cultural Policy (CLT), which allows for high visibility of the reports. Policy advice and technical support for legislative reform has i.e. resulted in the adoption of a Right to Information Law by the parliament in Morocco after a three-year long process. Related to the implementation of the UN Action Plan on the Safety of Journalists and the Issue of Impunity, with the support from Sida, UNESCO accomplished results in four major areas: judicial support, media curricula, policy reform and peace building. In the area of judicial support, a massive open online course (Mooc) called "The judges initiative", developed and implemented in a total of 21 countries in Latin America, stands out as particularly innovative and successful. According to UNESCO reporting, more than 7 500 individuals, judges, public prosecutors and lawyers were trained in best practice in international media legislation and were given access to an international database of court cases related to Freedom of Expression and Access to Information. There are several examples of courts of law issuing sentences based directly on the UNESCO training materials. Based on the successful experience in Latin America the Mooc was adapted and rolled out on the African continent. A specific expected result empowering women and youth the programme achieved results related to gender representation in and through media, as well as related to media and information literacy (MIL). The latter for example contributing to the production of a manual and tools to prevent and counter hate speech an online violence amongst youth and introducing MIL to Palestinian schools. 1 b) Empowering Local Radio Stations with ICTs. Specific countries: Burundi, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda. The project built the capacities of 27 local radio stations, located in six African countries, by strengthening long term skills of local radio journalists, technicians, volunteers, correspondents and station managers. Emphasis on the integration of ICTs allowed for the modernization of the radio stations' operations. Self-monitoring of the participating stations helped to document the outcome over time. For example, the final report notes that on an overall level there was an annual increase of 24% per year in the number of news stories produced following investigative techniques, which increases the potential to impact the communities and cause change. An expected result of the project was to reinforce the sustainability of the local radio stations, i.e. to generate revenues. Capacity was raised to establish financial plans and projections on financial needs and to diversify income. Examples of radio stations that developed income generations have been reported, i.e. through advertising via SMS. One difficulty however, noted in the evaluation, in working with radio is the lack of connectivity at local radio stations and a gap between digital communications and available equipment. 2. "Enhancing fundamental freedoms through the promotion of the diversity of cultural expression". Global scope with specific countries targeted: Burkina Faso, Cambodia, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Morocco, Rwanda, Senegal, Tunisia, Viet Nam, Zimbabwe. The project included country level capacity building to support participatory, transparent and informed systems of governance; multi-stakeholder meetings with governments, civil society and experts; production of global reports and information and monitoring tools to enhance evidence-based cultural policy monitoring. The project also supported an international expert facility with experts coaching national teams to write the quadrennial reports. Some of the experts also contributed to the global reports. Ministries of Culture of the 12 target countries and concerned UNESCO field offices were the primary implementation partners. This project has delivered some particularly strong results and even outstanding results, especially related to the development and enhancement on global norms and standards related to freedom of expression and artistic freedom. In 2014 when the project started, artistic freedom was not a well established concept neither in related to UNESCO's work on freedom of expression or in relation to the 2005 Convention. Successful results of the programme include: Policy dialogue between civil society and the government strengthened. The project introduced new mechanisms and platforms for policy dialogue with a wider range of stakeholders on a national level. Government officials and civil society have engaged and are talking in countries where this had not happened before to lay the ground for participatory policy making processes, for example in Rwanda. Inter-ministerial cooperation enhanced through new cooperation mechanisms in between ministries to work together to advance culture as a priority for sustainable development. Partnerships created for joint policy advocacy. The project raised awareness on the links between artistic freedom, press freedom, media diversity and the diversity of cultural expressions, creating bridges between media and cultural actors in their policy advocacy, i.e. the WPFD: New legislative and policy processes initiated in beneficiary countries, where the project inspired design or re-design of their cultural policies in line with the principles and goals of the convention. The project has inspired several beneficiary countries and other Parties to the Convention to design or re-design their cultural policies, in line with the guiding principles and goals of the Convention. Artistic freedom recognized as a UNESCO priority. The project played a catalytic role for making "artistic freedom" and the status of the artist a priority area of action in the UNESCO 39 C/5 Programme and Budget for 2018-2021. The inclusion of artistic freedom, for the first time within UNESCO's regular programme, represents a significant achievement and a positive indicator for the sustainable impact of the project. Synergies created between CLT and CI stakeholders to advance fundamental freedoms: the themes of artistic freedom and media diversity were instrumental for establishing closer links between the culture and media professionals and stakeholders. New result-based Global Monitoring Framework and instruments for information sharing. New tools such as the monitoring framework of the Convention, the Policy Monitoring Platform and the Global Report series were introduced to share good practices and highlight examples of relevant policies and measures drawn from the countries' quadrennial reports in order to support transparency, policy advocacy and evidence-based policy making globally. The Global Reports build on the countries' reporting on the Convention but use secondary data where the reporting is missing or weak. In 2018 UNESCO "Intergovernmental Committee for the protection and promotion of the diversity of cultural expressions" made the decision to include artstic freedom and gender equality in the obligatory reporting of political actions for the implementation of the 2005 Convention, which is a direct result of Sida's support. States report to UNESCO every four years. The first global report was presented in 2015 generated public debate on artistic freedom and gender equality around the world. Continued successful communication strategies and the development thereof for the second report in 2018 have continued to spur the debate as well as policy initiatives and increased interest in the culture policy field and culture and development on national and international levels. 3. Internet Universality Indicators The Internet Universality indicators have been developed through a process of desk research and consultation, undertaken by UNESCO with the support of a Consortium which is led by the Association for Progressive Communications (APC) and which includes ICT Development Associates, LIRNEasia, Research ICT Africa and DIRSI. The advice of the project’s Multistakeholder Advisory Board and of the UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS) has also been sought during the project. The indicators have been developed through two phases of consultations. The first consultation (2017) enabled the preparation of a draft framework and a set of indicators which were set out in the document Defining Internet Universality Indicators, published online and offline in December 2017. The Phase 2 consultation (2018), enabled all stakeholders to respond to this framework and draft indicators. A Phase 3 of the project comprising pre-testing and piloting was conducted so as to improve the final draft indicators to be considered in November 2018 by the International Council of UNESCO’s International Programme for the Development of Communication (IPDC). The IPDC adopted the indicator framework, which Sida assesses is a success and a strong result of the project. Synergies Sida's request for and continued encouragement of synergy outcomes in the programmes and projects as well as across the CI and CLT sectors created successful synergies and results, both at HQ and at field level. Intersectoral cooperation was generated and strengthened. This was manifested in successful joint launch events of Global Report 2018 and the World Trends Report as well as the 2005 Convention Team presence at the World Press Freedom Day in Helsinki 2016, Jakarta 2017 and Accra 2018. In an unprecedented way, reference to the linkages between freedom of expression and artistic freedom were integrated in the final Declaration adopted by the participants of the WPFD in Jakarta 2017: "Emphasising also the mutually reinforcing relationships between freedom of expression and all other rights and freedoms, including freedom of thought, freedom of conscience, as well as religious, academic and artistic freedom;" Moreover the Declaration calls on UNESCO to "Promote artistic freedom as a pillar of freedom of expression and as a cornerstone of participatory democracy, and support artistic creation and ensure access to cultural life for all members of society;". The 2018 Accra Declaration called on member states to encourage business models, including digital solutions, for creative thinkers to disseminate their work and connect to their audiences; the 2019 Addis Abeba Declaration called on member states to "put in place transparent and effective systems to protect journalists, including press cartoonists, artists, ‘artivists’ and others who are at risk of attack for exercising their right to freedom of expression, thereby ensuring that they can carry out their public watchdog role effectively, including during elections".
